words.ENTRY: a; strong form (also an, used before a vowel sound) indefinite article1.one: I'll have a cup of coffee.an apple and a pear2.(used when you are talking about something in general, not one particular example of it): A lion is a dangerous animal.3.(used for showing that somebody/something is a member of a group, class, or profession): She's a teacher.4.(used with some expressions of quantity): a lot of moneya few cars

about1adverb(informal) a little more or less than; approximately: It's about three miles from here to the center of town.I got home about 7:30.about2preposition1.on the subject of: a book about Spain
I don't like it, but there's nothing I can do about it. how/what about ...?1.(used when asking for information about somebody/
something or for somebody's opinion or wish): I'm going to have chicken. How about you?What about Ruth? What's she doing?2.(used when making a suggestion): How about going to a movie tonight?
<H>according to</H><audio>according_to.mp3</audio><PS>preposition</PS><D>as stated by somebody; as shown by something:</D> <X>According to Mick, it's a great movie.</X>
<H>across</H><audio>across.mp3</audio><PS>preposition</PS><D>on the other side of something:</D> <X>There's a bank across the street.</X>
<H>actor</H><audio>actor.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><D>a person whose job is to act in a play, movie, or television program:</D> <X>Brad Pitt is an actor.</X>
<H>actress</H><audio>actress.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><D>a woman whose job is to act in a play, movie, or television program:</D> <X>Julia Roberts is an actress.</X>

<H>actually</H><audio>actually.mp3</audio><PS>adverb</PS><NR>1.</NR><D>really; in fact:</D> <X>You don't actually believe her, do you?</X><dot><X>I can't believe that I'm actually going to England!</X><NR>2.</NR><D>although it may seem strange or surprising:</D> <X>He actually expected me to cook his dinner for him!</X><dot><X>Well, actually, I know a lot about computers: my dad's a programmer.</X>
adjectivenoun(grammar) a word used with a noun that tells you more about it: The adjective "hot" can come either before or after a noun, i.e. you can say "that is hot soup" or "that soup is hot."

adverbnoun(grammar) a word that adds information to a verb, adjective, phrase, or another adverb: In the sentence "Please speak slowly"; "slowly" is an adverb."Happily," "well," "always," "very," and "too" are all adverbs.

<H>after</H><su>1</su><audio>after.mp3</audio><PS>preposition</PS><NR>1.</NR><D>later than something:</D> <X>Shelley called just after six o'clock.</X><dot><X>After finishing my homework, I went out for a walk.</X><NR>2.</NR><D>following in order:</D> <X>C comes after B in the alphabet.</X><H>after</H><su>2</su><audio>after.mp3</audio><PS>conjunction</PS><D>at a time later than something:</D> <X>They arrived at the station after the train had left.</X><dot><X>After we finish our dinner, we usually sit outside on the patio.</X>

<H>afternoon</H><audio>afternoon.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><D>the part of a day between noon and about six o'clock:</D> <X>I'll see you tomorrow afternoon.</X><dot><X>She arrived at four o'clock in the afternoon.</X><dot><X>Are you busy (on) Friday afternoon?</X> <CF> good afternoon</CF> <D>(used when you see somebody for the first time in the afternoon)</D>
afterward (also afterwards) adverbat a later time: I met her at a party and saw her again soon afterward.Afterward, Nick said he hadn't enjoyed the movie.

<H>again</H><audio>again.mp3</audio><PS>adverb</PS><NR>1.</NR><D>once more; another time:</D> <X>Could you say that again, please?</X><dot><X>Don't ever do that again!</X><NR>2.</NR><D>in the place or condition that somebody/something was in before:</D> <X>It's great to be home again.</X><dot><X>I hope you'll soon feel well again.</X>

<H>alarm clock</H><audio>alarm_clock.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><D>a clock that you can set to make a noise at a particular time to wake you up:</D> <X>My alarm clock goes off at seven o'clock.</X><dot><X>She set the alarm for 6:30.</X>

alldeterminer; pronoun1.the whole of a thing: All (of) the food is gone.They ate it all.2.the whole of the period of time:
It rained all day.He worked hard all his life.3.every one of a group: All (of) my kids can swim.My kids can all swim.She's read all (of) these books.4.everything that; the only thing that:
I wrote down all I could remember.All I've eaten today is a slice of toast.

<H>along</H><audio>along.mp3</audio><PS>preposition</PS><NR>1.</NR><D>from one end to or toward the other end of something:</D> <X>I walked slowly along the beach.</X><NR>2.</NR><D>in a line that follows the side of something long:</D> <X>Wild flowers grew along both sides of the river.</X>

<H>also</H><audio>also.mp3</audio><PS>adverb</PS>(not used with negative verbs) <D>in addition; too:</D> <X>Mark speaks fluent French. He also speaks Chinese.</X><dot><X>The food is wonderful, and also very cheap.</X>

<H>always</H><audio>always.mp3</audio><PS>adverb</PS><NR>1.</NR><D>at all times; regularly:</D> <X>Why is the bus always late when I'm in a hurry?</X><NR>2.</NR><D>all through the past until now:</D> <X>I've always liked music.</X><NR>3.</NR><D>forever:</D> <X>I will always remember this moment.</X>
<H>amazing</H><audio>amazing.mp3</audio><PS>adjective</PS><D>causing you to be very surprised:</D> <X>She has shown amazing courage.</X><dot><X>I have an amazing story to tell you.</X>

<H>ambition</H><audio>ambition.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><NR>1.</NR><CF>ambition (to be/do something)</CF> <bracket>uncountable</bracket><D>strong desire to be successful, to have power, etc.:</D> <X>One problem with young people today is their lack of ambition.</X><NR>2.</NR><bracket>countable</bracket><D>something that you very much want to have or do:</D> <X>It's always been her ambition to travel around the world.</X>

<H>amusement park</H><audio>amusement_park.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>an open area with games for people to play and machines for them to ride on:</D> <X>The Wild West Train was my favorite ride at the amusement park.</X>

<H>and</H><audio>and.mp3</audio><PS>conjunction</PS><NR>1.</NR><D>(used to connect words or parts of sentences) also; in addition to:</D> <X>one woman, two men, and three children</X><dot><X>a boy and a girl</X><dot><X>Do it slowly and carefully.</X><dot><X>We sang and danced all night.</X><NR>2.</NR><D>(used when you are saying numbers) plus:</D> <X>Twelve and six is eighteen.</X><dot><X>It cost me a hundred and sixty dollars.</X><NR>3.</NR><D>then; following this or that:</D> <X>Come in and sit down.</X>

<H>angry</H><audio>angry.mp3</audio><PS>adjective</PS>(<DR>angrier</DR>; <DR>angriest</DR>) <CF>angry (with somebody) (at/about something)</CF>; <CF>angry (at somebody) (about something)</CF> <D>feeling or showing anger:</D> <X>Calm down. There's no need to get angry.</X><dot><X>My parents will be really angry if I get home late.</X>

answer1verb1.to say or write something back to somebody who has asked you something: I asked you a question; now please answer me.Answer all the questions on the form.2.to do something as a reply: I rang their doorbell but nobody answered.He hasn't answered my letter yet. (= written a letter back to me)answer2nouncountableanswer (to somebody/
something)1.something that you say, write, or do as a reply: The answer to your question is that I don't know.I wrote to them two weeks ago, and I'm still waiting for an answer.I knocked on the door and waited, but there was no answer.2.something that is written or said, trying to give the correct information asked for on a test or exam: What was the answer to the last question?to choose the right/wrong answer

any1determiner;pronoun1.(used in negative sentences and in questions. Compare to some.) some: We didn't have any lunch.I don't know any Canadians.Do you have any questions?He asked if we had any questions.2.(used for saying that it does not matter which thing or person you choose): Take any book you want.Any teacher would say the same.any2adverb(used in negative sentences and questions) at all; to any degree: I can't run any faster.Is there any more milk in the fridge?

<H>anything</H><audio>anything.mp3</audio><PS>pronoun</PS><NR>1.</NR>(usually in questions or negative statements) <D>one thing (of any kind):</D> <X>The fog was so thick that I couldn't see anything at all.</X><dot><X>Did you buy anything?</X><dot><X>That's amazing! I've never seen anything like it!</X><NR>2.</NR><D>any thing or things; it does not matter what:</D> <X>I'm starving! I'll eat anything.</X><dot><X>I'll do anything you say.</X>

<H>anywhere</H><audio>anywhere.mp3</audio><PS>adverb</PS><NR>1.</NR>(usually in questions or negative statements) <D>in, at, or to any place:</D> <X>I can't find my keys anywhere.</X><dot><X>Is there a post office anywhere near here?</X><NR>2.</NR><D>any place; it does not matter where:</D> <X>"Where should we go to eat?" "Oh, anywhere is fine."</X>

<H>apartment</H><audio>apartment.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a set of rooms that is used as a home (usually on one floor in a larger building):</D> <X>a three-bedroom apartment.</X><dot><X>I don’t live in a house, I live in an apartment.</X>

appearancenoun1.uncountablethe way that somebody/
something looks: A different hairstyle can completely change your appearance.
<H>architect</H><audio>architect.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a person whose job is to design buildings</D>

<H>around</H><audio>around.mp3</audio><PS>preposition</PS><NR>1.</NR><D>in various directions inside an area; in different places in a particular area:</D> <X>They walked around the town, looking in some of the stores.</X><NR>2.</NR><D>in a circle or following a curving path:</D> <X>The athlete ran around the track ten times.</X><dot><X>Go around the corner and it's the first house on the left.</X><dot><X>She had a bandage around her leg.</X><NR>3.</NR><D>near a place:</D> <X>Is there a bank around here?</X>

<H>arrive</H><audio>arrive.mp3</audio><PS>verb</PS><D>to reach the place to which you were traveling:</D> <X>We arrived home at about midnight.</X><dot><X>What time does the flight arrive in Toronto?</X>

asconjunction;preposition;adverb1.while something else is happening: The phone rang just as I was leaving the house.
As she walked along the street, she thought about her father.
2.as ... as (used for comparing people or things): Tom's almost as tall as I am.It's not as cold as it was yesterday.3.(used for talking about somebody's job): He works as a bus driver for the school district.

askverb ask (somebody) (about somebody/something)
to put a question to somebody in order to find out some information: We need to ask about the price."What time is it?" he asked.He asked what time it was.

<H>at</H><audio>at.mp3</audio><PS>preposition</PS><NR>1.</NR><D>(showing the position of something or where something happens):</D> <X>Turn left at the next intersection.</X><dot><X>We were at home all weekend.</X><dot><X>Are the kids still at school?</X><NR>2.</NR><D>(showing when something happens):</D> <X>I start work at 9 o'clock.</X><dot><X>at night</X>

<H>atmosphere</H><audio>atmosphere.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable, uncountable</bracket><D>the mood or feeling of a place or situation:</D> <X>There was a tense atmosphere during the final minutes of the game.</X>

<H>attraction</H><audio>attraction.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>something that attracts somebody/something:</D> <X>Washington D.C. offers all kinds of tourist attractions.</X><dot><X>One of the attractions of the job is having a company car.</X>

<H>avenue</H><audio>avenue.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a street in a town or city:</D> <X>I live at 12 Tennyson Avenue.</X><dot><X>at the corner of Sixth Avenue and 72nd Street</X>

awayadverb away (from somebody/something) to a different place or in a different direction: Go away! I'm busy!
I asked him a question, but he just looked away.
awesomeadjective(informal) very good; excellent: We went to an awesome party at Dave's house.Wow! That's totally awesome!

<H>awful</H><audio>awful.mp3</audio><PS>adjective</PS><NR>1.</NR><D>very bad or unpleasant:</D> <X>We had an awful vacation. It rained every day.</X><NR>2.</NR><D>terrible; very serious:</D> <X>I have some awful news for you.</X>
